title: Secondary – Cycle 2 – Progression of Learning - Physics (2011)
subject: Mathematics, Science and Technology

document.title: Secondary – Cycle 2 – Progression of Learning - Physics (2011)

23206FA8A6D443208323215A103107F7.description: Using tools to display information in various formats (e.g. data tables, graphs, diagrams)

B6FAD869078F490794B80ED38959EA63.description: Comparing different possible explanations for or solutions to a problem in order to assess their relevance (e.g. full-group discussion)

11DE72B87E9A43E18A10CFA5429FB8D1.description: Organizing information for a presentation (e.g. tables, diagrams, graphs)

4B4E5F7708844233800A6B4FC60823BF.description: Using different means of communication to propose explanations or solutions (e.g. oral presentation, written presentation, procedure)

8D760ECB6D4D4953939A9EE923BD50B8.description: Selecting relevant criteria to help him or her determine where he or she stands on a scientific or technological issue

34A0FF3346D844BAB733A624646BBDAF.description: Reasoning by analogy in order to process information and adapt scientific and technological knowledge

32E8546B049949CC8DBB511817B47683.description: Using different types of reasoning (e.g. inductive and deductive reasoning, comparison, classification, prioritization) in order to process information

B0760F97FCF94B42B3C24E6E5704D033.description: Dividing a complex problem into simpler subproblems

1D0599F02A5C4CCBAD3262A81E9FCEF2.description: Identifying the constraints and important elements related to the problem-solving situation

2648641783F648A4A79366E572DAF710.description: Selecting suitable techniques or tools for observation

D87A38D8A7414F928B79F5B6CDD0FDD5.description: Using a variety of observational techniques and tools

C0C40308FB7B4C17B65E7BA8ACFDBF5D.description: Using different tools for recording information (e.g. diagrams, notes, graphs, procedures, logbook)

A08AFCAB385D48B69B89A065A6CF9910.description: Using technical design to illustrate a solution (e.g. diagrams, sketches, technical drawings)

139F6575706743A08CF4C37E093F9014.description: Using different sources of information (e.g. books, newspapers, Web sites, magazines, experts)

1AE572ACC5544FF7B32EC5DC749D05A7.description: Considering various points of view on scientific or technological issues

3BA5B2B7FFBD4F39BEE64300751515C5.description: Generalizing on the basis of several structurally similar cases

C354667857B9428790308486E8DE30F9.description: Collecting as much scientific, technological and contextual information as possible to define a problem or predict patterns

48A1A59E93B54B41A822F0126FC4C68A.description: Ensuring that the procedure is appropriate and safe, and making the necessary adjustments

3716AE565EFF4469BBD4D68071E870D4.description: Using empirical approaches (e.g. trial and error, analysis, exploration using one's senses)

13DBB63F5FB24E7CB6E9E61547538B01.description: Using different types of reasoning (e.g. induction, deduction, inference, comparison, classification)

E5331AABC6FF4CCF8F5C4BB1AFF031E6.description: Examining his or her mistakes in order to identify their source

4AB739A94A6749BF808590D326AD7A69.description: Taking into account the constraints involved in solving a problem or making an object (e.g. specifications, available resources, time allotted)

0A3D692AA2074291BFC620ABE9DD724B.description: Imagining solutions to a problem in light of his or her explanations

052762C4C7FB4147AE77C69C5CF583BB.description: Anticipating the results of his or her approach

F7E1F3CB03774FA4A7C31A4358084630.description: Exploring various ways of solving the problem

D5A06FB3A922449FA52821BEAF9E13AA.description: Putting forward hypotheses (e.g. individually, in teams, as a class)

7DBA3D6C00C148E6BAB2ACD3A18EC4B0.description: Drawing a diagram for the problem or illustrating it

82375621ACC8448DA3F6AA6F8D66F8E8.description: Becoming aware of his or her previous representations

924B21F31A014A92A0C080E674CA0036.description: Referring to similar problems that have already been solved

64320DDE3FA04F5A91D59BD7E829BD8F.description: Distinguishing between the different types of information useful for solving the problem

FA535FF4C9054F03A255554885C568C6.description: Studying a problem or a phenomenon from different points of view (e.g. social, environmental, historical, economic)

70D60BC8CB384437A7A6FA23AC67AC88.description: Expresses the value of a measurement with its absolute or relative uncertainty (e.g. 24.1 ± 0.1 cm or 24.1 cm ± 0.4 %)

DD84502A0EAA4C1689EF18ABFCBDD056.description: Expresses a result with a significant number of digits that takes into account the errors related to the measure (e.g. a measurement of 10.35 cm taken with a ruler graduated in millimetres should be expressed as 10.4 cm or 104 mm)

596F0CD0893E453CB47F5550E2E173FD.description: Estimates the errors associated with the user and the environment when taking a measurement (e.g. in the case of a stopwatch, the error associated with reaction time is estimated to be 0.1 seconds)

FA127C6F95714799BB88848CFBB79C85.description: Determines the error attributable to a measuring instrument (e.g. the error in a measurement made using a dynamometer corresponds to half of the smallest division on the scale, the error in a measurement made using a measuring tape correcponds to the value of the smallest division on the scale)

C579C5B687D645DBB8508C341F47CE78.description: Chooses a measuring instrument by taking into account the sensitivity of the instrument (e.g. uses a stopwatch instead of an analogue clock)

FBD369776A124CFF9A9B03E0B09FC7C9.description: Carries out the required operations to ensure the accuracy of a measuring instrument (e.g. calibrates a probe, positions a measuring instrument properly in the setup)

130B7560C7ED44ADB3A8C104EA3B8788.description: Takes the same measurement several times to check the repeatability of the instrument used

80E6FEB2FB5B4D7EABECF94D91355E29.description: Verifying the repeatability, accuracy and sensitivity of measuring instruments

A088634157244C5F877F6C63DBD6ACA1.description: Uses observational instruments appropriately (e.g. photographic camera, video camera, probe)

DFE87A725A0F43ED977965B1E1F7D9AE.description: Uses laboratory materials and equipment safely (e.g. never aims a laser beam toward a person's face, makes sure the apparatus is properly secured)

0B274D1168CA462C9311D0A2813CFEFB.description: Safely using laboratory or workshop materials and equipment

F3D4D683C2C84A1C99C6FB0A16FA8354.description: Applies the mathematical relationships that make it possible to determine the position, orientation and height of an object or its image in the case of mirrors or lenses (M = hi/ho = -di/do ; 1/do + 1/di = 1/f)

336A37E11F0042AD9BD6A60861BF85A2.description: Determines the characteristics of the image formed in a given situation (mirrors and lenses)

58C93A4649D24B14897829D3518B8E35.description: Explains the distinction between a real image and a virtual image

91A59D419FC2405CB0A40B2C98CFD551.description: Explains the phenomenon of total internal reflection (e.g. mirage, fibre optics)

65994185833848709A253222ADE4F0B5.description: Explains qualitatively and quantitatively a phenomenon using the Law of Refraction (n1sin?1= n2sin?2) (e.g. a straw in a glass of water)

0B8E9E0A560E41FA82C4C0B79629F630.description: Determines, in experiments or mathematically, the indices of refraction of various media

965E00A210B3406F9EB452EC0DDEEB96.description: Defines the index of refraction of a medium as the ratio of the speed of light in a vacuum to the speed of light in that medium (n = c/v)

4D0C4D1836D84C1B9ADB1CFF0BDEC465.description: Measures the angles of incidence and the angles of refraction in a diagram or an experiment

207383EC034E42A496E0644D3C8C50A6.description: Identifies incident rays and refracted rays in a diagram or an actual situation

48B3E5FC2F78428E96249B1386BDC357.description: Explains qualitatively and quantitatively a phenomenon using the Law of Reflection (e.g. minimum height a mirror must have in order for a person to see the full length of his/her body, extent of a field of vision)

27AB6C1F4ABF4654BA9DCBE7D4F34997.description: Measures the angles of incidence and angles of reflection in a diagram or an experiment

1411D836AC17424D97B337407BAC7509.description: Distinguishes diffuse reflection from specular reflection in various situations

551333B012274579AD49590E9E16E04A.description: Identifies incident rays and reflected rays in a diagram or an actual situation

EA00F8AE6088498E9D0AF47B379C7B41.description: Defines a light ray as a theoretical structure indicating the direction of the propagation of light

E9B2205EA0DB4B539BF74F811DFC4758.description: Applies the mathematical relationship between power, work and time (P = W/?t)

81B1A53EF43F48748D30C37A080C7C54.description: Explains qualitatively the relationship between the power of a system, the work done and the time taken to do the work

D7821853B557437A92AC6B2B2374535B.description: Relationship among power, work and time

A71C44E6EDA24B79BABF400AD05B7D3A.description: Applies the mathematical relationship between elastic potential energy, the force constant and the change in length in a given situation (E = ½kl )

42690894AEBF4F5A8F27D37CAA58D078.description: Explains qualitatively the relationship between the energy of a helical spring, its force constant and the change in its length compared to its length at rest, in a given situation (e.g. the springs in a mattress)

1B9CFC7DD4A448B6BD651FC72D20F374.description: Analyzes quantitatively a transformation of mechanical energy in a given situation

D69B2A1AF3674F81B49C3477644FCE0C.description: Applies the mathematical relationships associated with kinetic energy, types of potential energy (gravitational, elastic), work and heat

A3D5622F73AE43BBA035AA23C9449477.description: Explains qualitatively a transformation of mechanical energy in a given situation (e.g. a merry-go-round in motion)

528C7CBE9E8D491CA63E19A9C72383EF.description: Determines the magnitude and direction of the vector associated with the balancing force of a system of forces

CD4EED005DCD4852834FDA26E8523ECF.description: Determines the magnitude and direction of the vector associated with the resultant force of a system of forces

335A7FAFA91043839C1DC80808416CBF.description: Equilibrium and resultant of several forces

6CA630E869E849AB8B2176044A869BF4.description: Uses vectors to represent the forces that act on a body

95700507450E4FEBA8A487AC342512EB.description: Explains qualitatively the effect of centripetal force on a body in motion

4050ED10434F405E87F1FFDBA2374A33.description: Determines the value of the force of friction in a given situation (force of friction = applied force - net force)

833909CD9576439C82A4B2DAC5EFF810.description: Names the factors that can affect the force of friction in a given situation (e.g. nature of the surfaces that are in contact, shape of a body that is moving in a fluid)

CDD344900D454336B87872D40CEDA2EB.description: Explains the possible effects of a frictional force (slows down, stops or impedes the motion of a body)

DDEB3E8B7424495FB74D39F347187FBB.description: Explains a phenomenon or how a technical object works, using Newton’s Laws

AA7CC2FB9D7443F3BAAFBFFA7D1C96B3.description: Describes qualitatively the law of action-reaction (Newton’s Third Law)

E63662EBF89D46A38B4832B0A856FCC7.description: Applies the mathematical relationship between the force acting on a body, mass and acceleration (F = ma)

11F691FCB4F04C45BC813B55FF744104.description: Describes qualitatively the relationship between the force acting on a body, its mass and its acceleration (Newton’s Second Law)

5A171CA8A23B41CF892F1C16AC23EB51.description: Describes qualitatively the law of inertia (Newton’s First Law)

12B8A222DDCB4F09A345F7706A864949.description: Determines the component of gravitational force parallel to the displacement of a body (e.g. inclined plane)

044792171B8E40C7B38AFCC46F9956B9.description: Associates the gravitational force of a body with its weight

283BB0CD458042479328658F2F1FB352.description: Associates the free fall of a body with the effect of gravitational force

5A7F27F8F74A4697B5B2441A943B709F.description: Compares the average values of gravitational acceleration on Earth and on the Moon (9,8 m/s on Earth, 1,6 m/s on the Moon)

0AAD4B9C94574FCC91C2A611DAF58906.description: Determines the position, displacement or instantaneous velocity of a projectile, or the time elapsed

422951E8F7A643A08A5220B7FB98A401.description: Explains the motion of a projectile (combination of uniform rectilinear motion and uniformly accelerated rectilinear motion)

54D5ED531C4340ABB4962DF685AF89F5.description: Determines the position, displacement, average velocity, instantaneous velocity or acceleration of a body on an inclined plane

B8873C6016EB4F8FA33E038DAA3D2EE1.description: Provides a qualitative explanation and uses a graph to illustrate the motion of a body on an inclined plane (position, displacement, average velocity, instantaneous velocity, acceleration)

94FB5D11B73D44319A021113C8112D2E.description: Motion of a body on an inclined plane

7093070251D148A5945D4C8D5836472D.description: Determines the position, displacement, average velocity, instantaneous velocity or acceleration of a free-falling body

4E80A1AA89454A7D9FCEB15770D8B9C4.description: Provides a qualitative explanation and uses a graph to illustrate the motion of a free-falling body (position, displacement, average velocity, instantaneous velocity, acceleration)

D4D6E9F69C6E465B8B1423C30D2BD600.description: Explains the distinction between average velocity and instantaneous velocity

1044FBB52D2047AFBBD32F28EAB7BDF2.description: Determines the instantaneous velocity of an object

E9AA140152424CA4978C9FE3492B28AF.description: Determines the average velocity of an object

3C0C4392E68A4AE296A8A6E8F2859357.description: Applies the mathematical relationship between acceleration, the distance travelled and the time (?d = vi?t + ½a?t ) in a given situation

C8897344632741D68EF4BC1908D9878A.description: Provides a qualitative explanation and uses a graph to illustrate the relationship between the acceleration of a body, the distance it travelled and the time interval

62D22298B7FC4664A46D771287EB6035.description: Relationship among acceleration, distance and time

30AFC33C12EA4F8AA55C830E5A68CBE0.description: Applies the mathematical relationship between acceleration, change in velocity and time (a = ?v/?t) in a given situation

E7FCABED09034C72B5A3A92F40105D06.description: Provides a qualitative explanation and uses a graph to illustrate the relationship between the acceleration of a body, the change in its velocity and the time during which this change occurs

B6F9BFDBB61D46F48C0C29DB1D33EC9F.description: Relationship among acceleration, change in velocity and time

F6D034808F1C4C99A584D40350363EBD.description: Applies the mathematical relationship between position with respect to the point of origin (displacement), velocity and time (?d = v?t) in a given situation

807763E7E9234D2781BFD8F42D5D6297.description: Provides a qualitative explanation and uses a graph to illustrate the relationship between the position of an object with respect to its point of origin (displacement), its velocity and the time during which it is in motion

BBA9AA2CF27E41B6A4034DA32A54D940.description: Relationship among position with respect to the point of origin, velocity and time

0CC0A02618484E13821194D753540325.description: Chooses a reference system suited to the situation
